header_summary:
A recent study highlighted in the Cryptology ePrint Archive by Tim Ruffing et al. examines the post-quantum security of Bitcoin's Taproot, concluding that quantum computing does not currently pose a significant threat to Bitcoin's script-path spends and suggesting a two-phase softfork for enhancing post-quantum security. [Read more](https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/1307). Additionally, the release of libsecp256k1 version 0.7.0 introduces major updates aimed at improving stability, efficiency, and API and ABI compatibility, alongside full support for CMake to facilitate easier integration for developers. [More details](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).

Jon Atack discusses the effective collaboration within the Bitcoin repository management team, highlighting the synergy between active daily editors and the valuable contributions of other editors in handling Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) issues through responsive communication. [Read Jon's perspective](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/8285fb0c-119b-42b8-a530-194650b87ebe@achow101.com/T/#mee9e8028310ff77b76459611a8e1d91a09b3ee20). In a separate development, a groundbreaking paper proposes a novel Proof of Useful Work (PoUW) model for blockchain consensus, potentially revolutionizing the efficiency and security of decentralized networks without the extensive energy costs associated with traditional Proof of Work (PoW) systems. [Explore the research](https://x.com/hashdag/status/1933544298810622335).

Lastly, the release of a new Bitcoin dataset and benchmarking tool from January to June 2025 aims to aid in fee estimation and analysis, reflecting the community's ongoing efforts to enhance transparency and research capabilities in the cryptocurrency space. [Access the dataset and tool](https://github.com/block/bitcoin-augur-benchmarking).

recent_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
recent_posts.summary:
- A study reveals Bitcoin’s Taproot is post-quantum secure in script-path spending under QROM.
- It proposes a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin, enhancing security against quantum attacks.
- Quantum computing poses less threat than classical computing to Taproot’s integrity for now.

recent_posts.title: libsecp256k1 v0.7.0 released
recent_posts.summary:
- Libsecp256k1 version 0.7.0 focuses on maintenance improvements affecting API and ABI compatibility.
- Notable updates include constant context objects adjustments and deprecation of old function aliases.
- Version 0.7.0 also introduces full support for CMake, facilitating easier integration for developers.

recent_posts.title: New BIP Editors: 1 Year Later
recent_posts.summary:
- Jon is satisfied with the current group dynamics, praising active daily management by himself and Murch.
- He appreciates the role of other editors who contribute through responsiveness in discussions on BIPs.
- This structure of having two editors actively involved daily and others as needed has enhanced collaboration.

recent_posts.title: New paper on Proof of Usable Work
recent_posts.summary:
- A new paper proposes using global matrix multiplication power for blockchain "merge mining." - It introduces a secure, efficient Proof of Useful Work model, challenging Bitcoin's energy use.
- This approach aligns coin issuance with productive computational work, offering a sustainable alternative.

recent_posts.title: Where does the 33.33% threshold for selfish mining come from?
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion highlights the critical role of precise timestamping in blockchain security and efficiency.
- It proposes novel timestamping methods, including astronomical observations, to bolster decentralization.
- Accurate timestamps influence blockchain operations, miner incentives, and the utility of cryptocurrencies.

recent_posts.title: Augur: Block’s Open Source Bitcoin Fee Estimation Library
recent_posts.summary:
- A new dataset and benchmarking tool for Bitcoin block fee spans have been released.
- The dataset covers January to June 2025, aiding researchers and cryptocurrency enthusiasts.
- Access to this resource is provided via a GitHub repository to encourage community feedback.

active_posts.title: Human meaningful witness versioning
active_posts.summary:
- Ava Chow proposes mnemonic allocation for Bitcoin Witness Versions for easier identification.
- This allocation method aims at enhancing user safety and understanding of transaction types.
- Proposal suggests mnemonics like "z" for compressed outputs, improving clarity in the Bitcoin ecosystem.

active_posts.title: Make pathological transactions with more than 2500 legacy signature operations non-standard
active_posts.summary:
- The activation of BIP54 poses risks of DoS attacks due to invalid legacy signatures.
- A proposal suggests classifying problematic transactions as non-standard to delay BIP54 activation.
- Bitcoin Core PR 32521 aims to enhance security against these risks in the future.

active_posts.title: Revisiting secp256r1 signatures (i.e. P256, mobile HSM support)
active_posts.summary:
- Adding P256 to Bitcoin could significantly improve security and user experience.
- Tapscript's compatibility with P256 could simplify its integration, enhancing hot wallet security.
- P256 support might enable leveraging secure mobile hardware, boosting Bitcoin's accessibility.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 enhancements boost Bitcoin's defenses against quantum threats by adopting P2TR.
- The proposal avoids quantum-vulnerable key-spend paths, enhancing long-exposure attack security.
- It outlines a plan for Post-Quantum signatures, allowing flexible, future integration of new algorithms.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- The discussion focuses on extending Bitcoin's timelock to ~10 years via bit 21 manipulation.
- A tool and code for testing extended timelocks are made available for review.
- The exploration assesses risks, use cases, and alternatives to protocol alteration for longer timelocks.

active_posts.title: Fee-Based Spam Prevention For Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Jager and Teinturier's initial LN protocols introduced Upfront and Hold Fees to cover routing costs.
- New enhancements add security measures against fee theft, integrating secrets and burn outputs for fee allocation.
- Revised protocols introduce distinct fee types and innovative collection methods to improve LN efficiency and reduce spam.

today_in_history_posts.title: Schnorr signatures BIP
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Russell O'Connor proposes changing the verification equation to "Let *R = sG + eP*".
- This modification aims to speed up verification by eliminating the need for negation.
- The revised method simplifies verification, maintaining the same workload while reducing steps.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lack of capacity field in channel_announcement makes life difficult. Why is it not there?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Sjors Provoost discusses blockchain nodes' abuse and bandwidth issues.
- Proposes nodes discard wrong messages and track UTXO sets to check capacity.
- Suggests prioritizing new channels and limiting historical block fetches to mitigate DOS risks.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive investments include storing cash or buying land without active management.
- Active investments require direct engagement, like developing land or managing rental properties.
- The article suggests stabilizing economies by backing fiat currencies with deflationary ones like Bitcoin.
